name: Yosemite National Park
description: Yosemite National Park, located in California’s Sierra Nevada mountains, is famed for its iconic granite cliffs, towering waterfalls, giant sequoias, and diverse ecosystems. Designated as a World Heritage Site in 1984, Yosemite stands as a symbol of the American conservation movement, largely inspired by the work of John Muir.

geology.summary: Yosemite’s landscape was shaped primarily by glacial erosion, carving U-shaped valleys, domes, and towering cliffs. The most famous features, such as Half Dome and El Capitan, are composed of granite formed over 100 million years ago.

wildlife.description: Yosemite supports over 400 species of vertebrates, including mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, and fish. Its diverse habitats range from oak woodlands to alpine tundra.

locations.name: El Capitan
locations.description: A 900-meter granite monolith popular among climbers worldwide, dominating the Yosemite Valley skyline.

locations.name: Half Dome
locations.description: An iconic granite dome rising 1,444 meters above the valley floor, accessible via a strenuous trail with cable-assisted ascent.

locations.name: Yosemite Falls
locations.description: One of the tallest waterfalls in North America, with a total drop of 739 meters, visible from many points in Yosemite Valley.

locations.name: Glacier Point
locations.description: A viewpoint offering panoramic vistas of Yosemite Valley, Half Dome, and Yosemite Falls.

locations.name: Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias
locations.description: Home to over 500 mature giant sequoias, including the Grizzly Giant and the California Tunnel Tree.

routes.name: Mist Trail
routes.description: One of Yosemite’s most popular trails, leading past Vernal and Nevada Falls with misty views and granite steps.

routes.name: Four Mile Trail
routes.description: A steep ascent from Yosemite Valley to Glacier Point, offering sweeping views of the valley and waterfalls.

routes.name: Mirror Lake Trail
routes.description: An easy trail offering reflections of Half Dome and seasonal water levels.

safety_tips: Stay away from cliff edges and wet granite surfaces, which can be extremely slippery.
Do not feed wildlife; keep all food stored in bear-proof containers.
Be prepared for sudden weather changes in higher elevations.
Carry sufficient water and sun protection when hiking.
In winter, watch for falling ice and snow near waterfalls.
